ch.aplu.android

Class GGMultiTouch

  • java.lang.Object
    • ch.aplu.android.GGMultiTouch

  • public class GGMultiTouch
extends java.lang.Object
    Singleton class used to report screen multi-touch events. Touch events are not restricted to the visible playground, but coordinates are reported in pixel coordinates relative to the upper-left vertex of the game grid window.

    Touch type sequence and pointer ID:
    - first finger press -> type: press, ID: 0
    - second finger press -> type: pointerPress, ID: 1
    - finger moves -> type: drag, ID: 0 or 1 depending which finger
    - first finger release -> type: pointerRelease: ID: 0
    - first finger press -> type: pointerPress, ID: 0
    - first finger release -> type: pointerRelease: ID: 0
    - second finger release -> type: release, ID 1

    Drag events are not cached, so if the callback method multiTouchEvent does not return fast enough, some drag events may get lost, but other event types are always reported.

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description

      Screen pressed by the first pointer
      static int release
      Screen released by the last pointer.

    • Method Detail

      • create

        public static GGMultiTouch create()
        Creates a GGMultiTouch instance with default values for the instance variables.

      • create

        public static GGMultiTouch create(GGMultiTouchListener listener,
                  int evt,
                  int x,
                  int y,
                  int pointerId,
                  int pointerCount)
        Creates a GGMultiTouch instance with given values for the instance variables. Keep in mind that when auto zoom is enabled, the real coordinates must be provided. To convert virtual (unzoomed) coordinates, use GameGrid.toReal().
        Parameters:
        listener - the listener instances that created the event
        evt - the event type (an or-combination of the predefined constants)
        x - the x-coordinate where the event occurred (pixel coordinates relative to the upper-left vertext of the game grid window)
        y - the y-coordinate where the event occurred (pixel coordinates relative to the upper-left vertext of the game grid window)
        Returns:
        a GGMultiTouch instance reference

      • getSource

        public GGMultiTouchListener getSource()
        Retrieves the GGMultiTouchListener reference that created the event.
        Returns:
        a reference to the GGTouchListener that created the event

      • getEvent

        public int getEvent()
        Retrieves the current event type as integer.
        Returns:
        one of the predefined constants

        public int getPointerId()
        Retrieves the current pointer id.
        Returns:
        the id of the pointer that caused the event

      • getPointerCount

        public int getPointerCount()
        Retrieves the current number of pointers
        Returns:
        the number of the pointers

      • getX

        public int getX()
        Retrieves the current x-coordinate of the touch position with respect to the upper left vertex of the visible area in pixels.

        The visible area corresponds to the full device window and is not restricted to the game grid window. (Therefore events are also generated, if a touch occurs within the status bar.) Use isInGrid() to check, if the coordinates are within the game grid window.

        To convert the coordinates to game grid locations, use toLocation() or toLocationInGrid().

        Keep in mind that even when auto zoom is enabled, the pixel coordinates are returned. To convert them to virtual (unzoomed) coordinates, use GameGrid.toVirtual().
        Returns:
        x-coordinate (pixel index) where the event occured

      • getY

        public int getY()
        Retrieves the current x-coordinate of the touch position with respect to the upper left vertex of the visible area in pixels.

        The visible area corresponds to the full device window and is not restricted to the game grid window. (Therefore events are also generated, if a touch occurs within the status bar.) Use isInGrid() to check, if the coordinates are within the game grid window.

        To convert the coordinates to game grid locations, use toLocation() or toLocationInGrid().

        Keep in mind that even when auto zoom is enabled, the pixel coordinates are returned. To convert them to virtual (unzoomed) coordinates, use GameGrid.toVirtual().
        Returns:
        y-coordinate (pixel index) where the event occured

      • getEventType

        public java.lang.String getEventType()
        Returns the event type as string.
        Returns:
        the event type
